description: Simplifying complex systems by focusing on high-level concepts and hiding lower-level details.
A step-by-step procedure or set of rules for solving a problem or performing a task.
Continuously varying signals that represent physical quantities.
The simulation of human intelligence in machines that are programmed to think and learn.
An interactive experience where digital information is overlaid onto the real world.
A limit on the amount of information that can be contained within a given finite region of space.
A number expressed in the base-2 numeral system, using only 0 and 1.
A branch of algebra involving variables with two possible values, true or false, and operations like AND, OR, and NOT.
An error or flaw in software or hardware that causes it to produce incorrect or unexpected results.
The primary component of a computer that performs most of the processing inside a computer.
The delivery of computing services over the internet, including storage, processing, and software, on a pay-as-you-go basis.
The degree to which a system or problem is complicated and difficult to understand or solve.
Reducing the size of data for storage or transmission efficiency.
The ability of a problem to be solved by a computer algorithm.
Problem-solving that involves formulating problems and solutions in a way that a computer can execute.
An electronic device that processes data according to instructions stored in its memory.
The design and organization of a computer's core components, including the CPU, memory, and input/output systems.
The use of computers to process information or perform tasks.
The execution of multiple sequences of operations simultaneously within a computing system.
A specific way of organizing and storing data in a computer so that it can be accessed and modified efficiently.
An organized collection of data that can be easily accessed, managed, and updated.
Breaking down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable parts.
A system in which no randomness is involved in the development of future states.
Representing data using discrete values, often binary code.
A model where components of a software system are shared among multiple computers to improve performance and efficiency.
A complex network or interconnected system of entities, often used to describe a community of interacting organisms and their environment or a community of interrelated companies and technologies.
The integration of computing systems into devices that are not typically considered computers, designed to perform specific tasks within larger systems.
The process of converting data into a coded format to prevent unauthorized access.
The physical components of a computer system.
Data that is processed and organized in a meaningful way.
The communication between an information processing system and the outside world, including devices such as keyboards, monitors, and printers.
A set of electronic circuits on a small chip of semiconductor material.
A basic building block of a digital circuit that performs a logical operation on one or more binary inputs.
A subset of AI where computers learn from data and improve their performance over time without being explicitly programmed.
A large, powerful computer that handles the processing for many users simultaneously.
Malicious software designed to harm, exploit, or otherwise compromise a computer system.
The component of a computer that stores data and instructions for quick access by the CPU.
The value of a network is proportional to the square of the number of connected users.
A small, relatively inexpensive computer with a microprocessor as its central processing unit.
A midsized computer that is more powerful than a microcomputer but less powerful than a mainframe.
The observation that the number of transistors on a microchip doubles approximately every two years, increasing computational power.
The observation that tasks requiring high-level reasoning are easier for computers, while tasks requiring sensorimotor skills are harder.
A group of interconnected computers that can share data and resources.
A computational model inspired by the human brain's network of neurons, used in machine learning and AI.
Software with source code that anyone can inspect, modify, and enhance.
The software that manages a computer's hardware and software resources and provides common services for computer programs.
A repeated or regular arrangement of elements or data.
A computer designed for use by one person at a time.
A set of instructions that a computer follows to perform a task.
A formal language used to write instructions that a computer can execute.
An advanced computing paradigm that uses quantum bits (qubits) to process information exponentially faster than classical computers.
Computing systems that respond to inputs or events within a guaranteed time frame.
A material with electrical conductivity between that of a conductor and an insulator, used in electronic devices.
A function or set of functions provided by a system to meet a specific need.
The programs and other operating information used by a computer.
The high-level structure of a software system, defining its components and their interactions.
The application of engineering principles to software development in a methodical way.
The human-readable instructions written by a programmer that define what a computer program does.
A specific condition or status of a system at a particular point in time.
An extremely powerful computer used for complex simulations and calculations.
An abstract computational model that can simulate any computer algorithm.
The concept of embedding computing capabilities into everyday objects to make them smart and interconnected.
A simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.
A computer architecture model that describes a system where the computer's memory holds both instructions and data.
